One failure with that many people on board (including potential collateral damage) would be disastrous for SpaceX. Elon's statement that the ticket will include; "but also, you might die," is not respecting the seriousness of such a problem. SpaceX is regulated by the US government. If there's catastrophic loss of passengers then there will be an inquiry and likely an angry general or admiral to head it up (like with shuttle Columbia). They will find negligence and congress will feel obligated to take a reactive measure. Negative public perception will also hurt them. We all know the fate of the Concord SST after it crashed near Paris. Even a 1000:1 success/failure rate is too low. It will happen because they will lose respect for the gigantic bomb that the passengers are sitting atop after numerous successful launches. That's what happened with Challenger and Columbia, even with maintenance scrutiny that was already intensive.

Also, the lack of a launch abort system is absurd. I don't even know how Elon would get that past a regulatory wall considering that he had to have one (and test it) for the crewed Dragon capsule. Lack of an abort system is why the crew of Challenger didn't make it. We know that they were alive after the explosion and that the crew cabin continued on its ballistic trajectory with buttons continuing to be pressed.

I'm skeptical about the rocket truly replacing airliners, especially considering airplane technology is also advancing. But what I do see is the potential of opening up space tourism for the masses. A 10,000 thousand dollar trip to outer space on the BFR could become a possibility. At 10 grand, you don't need to be wealthy to travel to space. Today we have individuals who are middle class blowing through 10 grand on vacations, I'm sure you can find a middle class individual who is a massive space enthusiast who would be willing to pay that price for several hours in space. Since a tourist rocket wouldn't be focused on getting from point A to point B in the fastest time, I do suppose it could easily spend several hours in space before landing in Shanghai.

Another possibility is docking in potential space hotels if one wants to spend several days. Now at that point it becomes pretty expensive. But at if you were able to get the cost of sending a person to space for 10,000 dollars, that could open the doors to new industries in space, including space hotels. There will be more demand to research and develop such a system.

Just saw this video. I recomend you check out USMC project "SUSTAIN" Small Unit Space Transportation. The Marine Corp. Has wanted this capability since the Early 50's. Every decade they have a study group analyse the technology and each time they have decided that the technology just wasn't there yet, and that it would cost to much and that the Marine Corp. had other needs that were more pressing (The Air Force has had similar studies under the project name "Hot Eagle"). I suspect that SpaceX may want to use the BFS (or sub-scale BFS) to meet that need (I note that G. Shotwell mentioned "military" in a recent talk regarding the BFR). This would give them the experience needed to get the BFS certified by the FAA for civilian use. BTW the BFR/BFS is business and elite traveler/cargo solution. This is for those who could afford to take the Concord when that was a thing.

Rockets will never be as safe as aircraft. Due to the enormous stresses (heat and mechanical) on the air frame as well as due to the fact that you can't test a rocket as reliably as you can an aircraft. Space X's dozen or so successful landings are very impressive on their own right but they are FAR from proving the reliability required for a passenger aircraft. It would only take one failure to make it a 87% reliability which is totally unacceptable.
In addition, such an earth transportation rocket will essentially behave like a ballistic missile and as such no country will allow it to land anywhere near its borders (how can you be sure it's not actually a missile? or a BFR loaded with explosives? Since most countries lack the capability to shoot down ballistic missiles they won't allow such a vehicle to be flown into their territory.

A note on the "Scrub" portion: Yes a scrub usually requires that you wait a couple of days for the next launch opportunity, but the main reason for that is orbital dynamics and geometry. You have to wait until whatever you're trying to catch (either the ISS or a particular empty spot in an orbit) is passing more-or-less overhead of the launch point. With suborbital flights, this isn't a problem. The relationship between launch and landing points is fixed, so I suspect scrubs wouldn't be much more of a problem than they are with today's airliners.

This will never work for a myriad of reasons the most important being safety. At the current standards no one in their right mind would board one of these on a regular basis unless they had a death wish. The sheer number of rocket engines used is also a big problem here. Rocket engines are subjected to extreme operating conditions and failure in just one of those 30+ engines could bring down the entire thing. Second comes the extreme cost of putting something like this even into a low orbit. Passengers can expect to pay millions of dollars for a ride. So even if this thing does work as advertised it would be nothing more than a taxi for the extremely rich.

The reliability and safety needed for this plan is the same sort of reliability and safety needed for space tourism. Developing the capability for one goes a long way towards developing the capability for the other.

Yes, the security check and such will add to that "less than an hour" flight time, but then again it already does. The listed flight time DFW to Honolulu (8 hours) only counts time in the air; you're supposed to get to the airport two hours early. So that's ten hours, not counting the time it took you to get to the airport.
Now, if we assume an hour's flight time for the same trip on the BFR (and for DFW, so much for a sea launch) and fully three hours on both ends of the flight,* that's still an hour less than just the flight time on an airliner, and most of it not cooped up in your economy-class (or even first class) seat. It's three full hours less counting everything, and hey, if we're going to count security checks and such for BFR Air, we need to count it for United or American as well.

Just an FYI, you mixed up some of the stats and video from the old version of the BFR. For example, the new version plans to land using only 2 engines.

I do think given enough time this very well can be possible but NOT VIABLE:
- Even high cost airplane seats are nowadays actually not good business (middle price seats make more money for most of the companies). Flying a rocket will also never get the chance to lower the price (as no mass transportation possible).

- Even if you get the reliability close to an airplane (99.something%) there is a big difference between the type of accidents that can happen and also how one can survive if an accident occurs. Airplane accidents can happen mid flight and in some cases people can be saved. Most of the rocket failures happen while takeoff and landing (and always with an explosion) so there realistically will not be any survivors.

- Rest of the problems are as mentioned in the video such as having to land far away (because of noise and other considerations), long preparation time and of course the last and one of the most hardest challenge, the international laws about rocket travel from country to country.

So to summarize: There will not be enough people to trust their lives and their money to travel from one place to another just to save some hours (from a usual max 16h airplane flight down to 3 or 4 h rocket flight assuming all the preparations etc..). Only reason might be the chance to fly in space to see the earth (but that could be done much more safe and easier without the hassle of trying to land them to another country).

@Everyday Astronaut: You say those are "suborbital hops", that don't require the full performance of the ship, but I think you are mistaken. First, Musk said in the presentation that the passengers would be traveling at 27000 km/h, that is orbital speed.

Then, if you do the math, a purely ballistic trajectory for the NY-Sidney trip he listed in the video would need more delta-v than an orbital insertion and subsequent deorbit. Even the smaller trajectories like NY-London aren't really viable via a suborbital hop, as the apoapsis of such trajectory will be about 1000km: well into the Van Allen belts. EDIT: it is possible to do balistic trajectories with limited apoapsis, but then the delta-v requeriment is higher, surpassing orbital delta-v earlier. See this document: https://isulibrary.isunet.edu/opac/doc_num.php?explnum_id=95

I think those are orbital launches, with the peculiarity that they don't complete an entire orbit.

EDIT: That document I linked don't seem to explore such orbital launch possibility, but is very through on all aspects of suborbital passenger transportation. You could do several videos dissecting it. I'm also not sure about my earlier numbers on the time of suborbital vs orbital traveling, as accounting for launching and reentry is hard.
